Title: Fix vehicles missing the route if autopilot enabled too late
Body: #### Description If the simulator is running at high FPS the following snippet may fail ```py vehicle = world.spawn_actor(bp transform) vehicle.set_autopilot() ``` The reason currently we use a finely tuned combination of trigger boxes and spawn points placed on top of them(*) if the "set autopilot" message arrives after the vehicle has fallen inside the trigger box the waypoints are not assigned to its controller. I've made the controllers check if they're inside a route planner when the autopilot is enabled and retrieve a route if so. (*) Workaround for reusing the old autopilot we newer OpenDrive based navigation. #### Possible Drawbacks This adds quite some overhead to the "set autopilot" function but isn't called very often. Hopefully we'll get rid of the old autopilot system soon anyway. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1482)

Title: Reworked OpenDrive parser
Body: #### Description Since we had a limited OpenDrive parsing recently appeared the need to expand it. - Now the whole OpenDrive is parsed and not only what we initially need. - The internal structure is more similar to OpenDrive itself so it is more expandable and queries are easy. #### Python API Changes Our idea always is not to change how the Python API is used once we add new functionalities but in this case this was not possible. ###### Additions: * ~~**carla.Waypoint.id**: Unique identifier for a Waypoint based on the hash of it's `road_id` `section_id` `lane_id` and `s`.~~ (already in master added section_id) * **carla.Waypoint.section_id**: Refers to OpenDrive's [`laneSection`](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=21) number used as an id. * ~~**carla.Waypoint.s**: The [`s`](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=15) parameter of OpenDrive it defines the position along the reference line measured in meters from the beginning of the track calculated in the XY-plane.~~ (already in master) * **carla.LaneType**: Define the type of lane. The most common are _NONE_ _Driving_ _Shoulder_ _Sidewalk_ _Bidirectional_ and _Parking_ although OpenDrive use [more of them](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=93). These enums can be used as flags for queries. * **_Extended_ carla.LaneMarking**: + **type** Defines the [types](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=92). + **color**: Defines the [color](http://opendrive.org/docs/OpenDRIVEFormatSpecRev1.4H.pdf#page=92). + **lane_change** contains the lane change information of a single road mark indicating from which side of it you are allowed to cross. + **width**: Width of the road mark. * **carla.Waypoint.right_lane_marking** / **carla.Waypoint.left_lane_marking**: Returns a `carla.LaneMarking` for the right or left Waypoint's lane marking. ###### Changes: * **carla.LaneMarking** is not an enum anymore but an object. The enum is now **carla.LaneMarking.type**. * **carla.Waypoint.lane_type** doesn't work with strings anymore now uses an enum `carla.LaneType`. * **carla.Map.get_waypoint(location project_to_road=True lane_type=carla.LaneType.Driving)**: you can use it like before and will work as expected but now accepts a `carla.LaneType` that can be used as a flag to filter lane types for instance: `carla.Map.get_waypoint(location project_to_road=True lane_type=(carla.LaneType.Driving | carla.LaneType.Sidewalk)` will search for the nearest waypoint on the center of a _Driving_ or _Sidewalk_ lane. ###### More * Allow "carla.Map" object to be constructed from a XODR file (now it can be constructed without connecting to the simulator). * New functionality FileSystem::ListFolder. * Const and non-const versions of iterator::make_map_{values keys}_iterator now they also work on references instead of copies. * Add additional repo for testing resources (OpenDrive files) automatically downloaded when running unit tests. #### To Do - [x] Update CHANGELOG - [x] Update python_api.md - [x] Fix LaneCrossingCalculator - [x] ~~Test OpenDriveActor~~ (done in a different branch) - [x] Fix uses of `lane_type == 'driving'` (replace with `lane_type == carla.LaneType.Driving`) - [x] Fix uses of `waypoint.next(precision)[0]` --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1451)

Title: Bernatx recorder anim
Body: #### Description ##### Added new features to the recorder: - For vehicles the wheels are recorded and replayed correctly in function of the steering thruttle and brake applied. - For walkers they walk with full animation on playback ##### There are some bug fixes in the recorder system: - Fixing the camera following when a new map is loaded by the recorder. The wrong variable was used in that case ('FollowingId' instead of the 'ThisFollowingId') - Fixing positions at start of replayer if another replayer was play. The second time the replayer is called the actors were interpolated with its previous position and the new one but at the beginning the previous position was where the previous replayer leaves the actor so the actors were interpolated from its current position and the new position they need to go and the effect was that the actors were sliding fast to its new position for a short time (only in 1 frame). - The API function 'show_recorder_file_info' was showing the wrong parent id of an actor. It was showing the same id than the child actor because was using the wrong field name ('DatabaseId' instead of 'DatabaseIdParent'). - Some fixes in the 'start_recording.py' script that was not recording properly the actors destruction at end of the script execution. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Linux 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.21 #### Possible Drawbacks The recorded files created before this update can be replayed but the animation will not play. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1568)

Title: Added waypoint s junction_id
Body: #### Description Now you are able to use `carla.Waypoint.junction_id` to get the current's junction identifier (signed integer) in a case is `-1` the current waypoint is **not** a junction. This is useful for knowing which roads are inside the same junction. Also deprecated (but still can be used) attribute `carla.Waypoint.is_intersection` is now called `carla.Waypoint.is_junction`. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 & 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.21 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1509)

Title: Compile with extra warnings
Body: #### Description After noticing there were a lot of possible bugs specially related to narrowing conversions I switched on a lot more warnings for compiling LibCarla - `-Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wdeprecated -Wshadow -Wuninitialized -Wunreachable-code -Wpessimizing-move -Wold-style-cast -Wnull-dereference -Wduplicate-enum -Wnon-virtual-dtor -Wheader-hygiene -Wconversion -Wfloat-overflow-conversion` To do so I had to fix a lot of things - Included external libraries (boost rpc) as system to suppress warnings in those headers. - Fixed all the warnings that popped up specially related to `-Wconversion`. - Disallowed implicit conversions between Vector3D/FVector and Vector2D/FVector2D this uncovered a bug in the VehiclePhysicsControl (center of mass in centimeters). - Added more levels of assertions (effectively throwing exceptions in release) and use them in some parts of the code. #### Possible Drawbacks Some of the warnings can be annoying to developers some times but I believe this can ensure that a minimum quality is met and can avoid some bugs. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1571)

Title: RPC server optimizations
Body: #### Description Several optimizations and small refactoring most remarkable the server now won't wait for game-thread tasks if the client call them asynchronously this greatly increases the load of messages that the server can parse. - Added metadata to messages now only contains info on whether the call was async but later we can reuse this for client ids and permissions. - Removed dynamic allocations when possible (removed `std::function` and `std::shared_ptr` from function bindings). - Refactored `AsioThreadPool` and test `ThreadPool` into a generic `carla::ThreadPool` it also uses the same tricks to avoid dynamic allocations. - Moved methods in "Overload.h" to its own `carla::Functional` class. Client and server interfaces remain unchanged :+1: #### Possible Drawbacks Now we uncovered another issue if you send requests to the server too fast some of the messages might get lost; maybe an issue of rpclib but we should investigate further. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1552)

Title: Upgrade to Unreal Engine 4 22
Body: #### Description Upgraded the following - Upgraded to UE4.22 - Upgraded to clang-7 - Upgraded to gtest-1.8.1 - Prepared to upgrade to Boost 1.70 (not upgrading due to bug in Boost.Variant) #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 Windows 10 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 3.5 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 - - - #### How to upgrade your machine Download UE4.22 ```sh git clone --depth=1 -b 4.22 https://github.com/EpicGames/UnrealEngine.git ~/UnrealEngine_4.22 cd ~/UnrealEngine_4.22 ./Setup.sh && ./GenerateProjectFiles.sh && make ``` Set env variable UE4_ROOT in `~/.bashrc` and `~/.profile` ```sh export UE4_ROOT=$HOME/UnrealEngine_4.22 ``` Install clang-7 ```sh wget -O - https://apt.llvm.org/llvm-snapshot.gpg.key|sudo apt-key add - sudo apt-add-repository "deb http://apt.llvm.org/xenial/ llvm-toolchain-xenial-7 main" sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get install clang-7 lld-7 sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/clang++ clang++ /usr/lib/llvm-7/bin/clang++ 170 sudo update-alternatives --install /usr/bin/clang clang /usr/lib/llvm-7/bin/clang 170 ``` Clean Carla (open new terminal so the environment is set) ```sh make clean rm -rf ./Build ``` Update Content (or pull changes from Content repo) ``` ./Update.sh ``` then test ```sh make CarlaUE4Editor make check ``` --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1618)

Title: Fix dead lock when loading a new map in synchronous mode
Body: #### Description It seems we forgot to reset the settings after a new world is loaded the intended behaviour was to reload the map with default settings because a fresh new map is created and in fact the new world had the settings reloaded but the engine was not properly notified thus creating inconsistent state. The following works now (also without ticking in between). ```py client = carla.Client('localhost' 2000) client.set_timeout(2.0) world = client.get_world() while True: print('new world: enable sync mode.') world.apply_settings(carla.WorldSettings(synchronous_mode=True)) for _ in range(0 10): time.sleep(1) world.tick() world.wait_for_tick() print('tick!') world = client.reload_world() ``` Fixes #1412. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1588)

Title: Manishthani load props definition
Body: #### Description Users can now register their own props with `.fbx` format and make these props available through the existing Carla Blueprint Library API. Also these props can be spawned maintaining compatibility with semantic segmentation tags. To do so the following steps should be done: 1) Create a folder called `FBXImporter` inside Carla root folder 2) Place all your props in `.fbx` format inside `FBXImporter` folder. 3) Inside `FBXImporter` folder create a JSON File with the name of your package and with extension `.PropRegistry.json`. For example `YourPackageName.PropRegistry.json` 4) Store in that file a JSON Array called `definitions` which will contain JSON Objects with relevant information for importing a prop such as: - name: The name of your prop this name is the one that will be registered in the Carla Blueprint Library - source: The path to your `.fbx` file. - size: The size of your prop. String Values can be: `tiny` `small` `medium` `big` and `huge` - tag: The semantic segmentation tag. An example of `.PropRegistry.json` file would be: ```json { "definitions": [ { "name": "Prop01" "size": "medium" "source": "SM_Prop_1.fbx" "tag": "Pole" } { "name": "Prop02" "size": "medium" "source": "SM_Prop_2.fbx" "tag": "Roads" } ] } ``` 5) Run the script `import_fbx.py` located inside the carla `Util` folder. Once the script has finished each prop located in the `FBXImporter` will be available inside Carla Content in Unreal in path: `Content/YourPackageName/Static/PropTag/PropName/PropSource` and also will be included in the Carla Blueprint Library so they can be queried and spawned as well. Fixes # #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04LTS * **Python version(s):** 2.7.12 and 3.5.4 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.21 #### Possible Drawbacks --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1603)

Title: Improving visual quality of the rgb scene capture
Body: #### Description Added temporal aliasing to screen captures with post processing. This gets rid of the jaggies during motion. Set the target gamma to 1.4. I found this value to be the best. It minimises the brightness difference between the screen capture and the main camera. There is still a small difference on some monitors. Title: Physics layer friction
Body: #### Description **Friction Triggers** are triggers that can be added on runtime and let users define a different friction of the vehicles' wheels when being inside those type of triggers. For example this could be useful for making slippery surfaces in certain regions of a map dynamically. In order to spawn a friction trigger using `PythonAPI` users must first get the `trigger.friction` blueprint definition and then set the following necessary *attributes* to that blueprint definition: - `friction`: The friction of the trigger box when vehicles are inside it. - `extent_x`: The extent of the bounding box in the X coordinate. - `extent_y`: The extent of the bounding box in the Y coordinate. - `extent_z`: The extent of the bounding box in the Z coordinate. Once done that define a *transform* to specify the location and rotation of the friction trigger and simply call the spawn_actor(trigger_blueprint trigger_transform attach_to=None) method inside `carla.World`. Fixes #1442 and fixes #1420 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 LTS * **Python version(s):** Python 2.7.12 and Python 3.5.2. * **Unreal Engine version(s):** Unreal Engine 4.21 #### Possible Drawbacks --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1562)

Title: Set vulkan as default graphics api for linux Changed make files to allow user to start
Body: …unreal editor with vulkan or opengl #### Description Since Unreal 4.21 Unreal picks Vulkan instead of OpenGL as the default graphics API for Linux. If Vulkan is not installed on the user's system or the graphics driver or gpu does not support it then Unreal will detect this automatically and use OpenGl 4.5 instead. Vulkan is a lower level graphics API and performs better than OpenGL. Users who enable it should see a significant increase in fps when running the simulator. To use Vulkan install on your system along with latest graphics driver using the following tutorial: https://linuxconfig.org/install-and-test-vulkan-on-linux Currently 415 is the latest driver so replace 396 with 415. vulkaninfo | less command can be used to check that vulkan is working on your system. You should be able to see details about your graphics card. This PR updates the Unreal project settings to add Vulkan to the list of RHIs. Unreal should pick Vulkan instead of OpenGL by default once vulkan is installed on your system. Note: This change only effects Linux. DirectX 11/12 is used on Windows and Unreal does not support Vulkan on Windows currently. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** irrelevant * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22.1 * **GPUs:** GTX 1080 and RTX 2070 #### Possible Drawbacks GPUs below NVidia 900 series may be better off using OpenGL. If this is the case OpenGL can be enabled when launching the unreal editor with the CARLA make script by doing the following: make launch ARGS=--use-opengl --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1639)

Title: Do not cache actor parent on each actor
Body: #### Description A pointer to the actor's parent was kept on each actor thus this pointer was needed to initialize new actor instances which carried its own problems (#1724). By allowing finding a single actor by id (using episode's cached result if present) we can stop caching the parent in the actor and keep only the id thus is easier to create a new instance. - Fixes #1724. - Allow finding single actors by id in PythonAPI. - Improved complexity when finding traffic light associated to vehicle. #### Possible Drawbacks `actor.parent` might do an RPC call if the actor was not yet cached this was happening anyway but now is "lazy-initialized". --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1744)

Title: Adding world snapshot to Python API
Body: #### Description A world snapshot represents the state of every actor in the simulation at a single frame a sort of still image of the world with a timestamp. This is meant to solve all the synchronization issues when retrieving actor locations now is possible to record the location of every actor and make sure all of them were captured at the same frame without the need of using synchronous mode. It can also be used to remove the flickering in scripts like no-rendering mode. This is a concept that already existed internally but wasn't exposed in the API. It actually doesn't add any overhead at it simply returns a reference to the episode state that is kept internally. For some more context see https://github.com/carla-simulator/carla/issues/1274#issuecomment-465567495. ```py # Retrieve a snapshot of the world at this point in time. world_snapshot = world.get_snapshot() # Wait for the next tick and retrieve the snapshot of the tick. world_snapshot = world.wait_for_tick() # Register a callback to get called every time we receive a new snapshot. world.on_tick(lambda world_snapshot: do_something(world_snapshot)) ``` This is a **change in the API** now tick related functions pass a world snapshot instead of a timestamp. However I added the same properties the timestamp had to the snapshot (as deprecated) so no need to change client code yet (though it should be changed cause eventually we'll remove these properties). The world snapshot contains a timestamp and a list of actor snapshots. Actor snapshots do not allow to operate on the actor directly as they only contain data about the physical state of the actor but you can use their id to retrieve the actual actor. And the other way around you can look up snapshots by id (_average O(1)_ complexity). ```py timestamp = world_snapshot.timestamp timestamp.frame_count timestamp.elapsed_seconds timestamp.delta_seconds timestamp.platform_timestamp for actor_snapshot in world_snapshot: actor_snapshot.get_transform() actor_snapshot.get_velocity() actor_snapshot.get_angular_velocity() actor_snapshot.get_acceleration() actual_actor = world.get_actor(actor_snapshot.id) actor_snapshot = world_snapshot.find(actual_actor.id) ``` #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 and 3.5 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1776)

Title: Enabling texture streaming and adding support for texture streaming t
Body: …o scene captures #### Description Scene captures now have support for texture streaming. Their view information is now registered with Unreal's streamer each tick. This also takes the texture size and FOV into account. I turned texture streaming on in project settings. Our texture pool is 2000mb. This can be increased but should be fine. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.5 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** Unreal 4.22.2 #### Possible Drawbacks With texture streaming back on there might be side effects. Reviewers should test the hell out of it. To test texture streaming on scene capture its best to reduce the texture pool size to 20mb and compare textures between scene capture camera when the main camera is very far below the map (ensures higher mips not loaded for it) and the main camera. Texture pool size can be set by following Unreal console command: r.Streaming.PoolSize=1500 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1721)

Title: Caching rendered towns to make next executions faster in no rendering mode
Body: #### Description *No rendering mode* can save and load cached towns images in order to make the rendering of maps faster. In the first execution of the `no_rendering_mode.py` script for a specific town the execution will be slow since it needs to render the selected town image and when rendering finishes it will also save the rendered image inside `./PythonAPI/examples/cache/no_rendering_mode/` directory. Therefore in further executions of the script it will **not** render the map again instead it will just read the previously rendered image of the town saving users a lot of time when running the script. Note that *No rendering mode* will update the corresponding cached town image if its OpenDrive file content changes. Finally refactored some code to make it more consistent with other other `PythonAPI` example scripts . #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04LTS * **Python version(s):** 2.7.12 and 3.5.2 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1736)

Title: New PythonAPI documentation
Body: ## Moved to New python reference #1814 #### Description Since we had some issues parsing the `C++` code to autogenerate the PythonAPI docs we decided to have a few `YAML` files with the Python documentation. Regarding #1333 this same method will be used to easily generate Python [stub files](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/#stub-files) in the future. #### How to test Install `MkDocs` if necessary: ``` pip install mkdocs ``` Go to Carla directory and start the `MkDocs` in localhost: ``` cd carla mkdocs serve ``` Open a browser and go to http://127.0.0.1:8000/python_api/ After changing some of the `YAML` files just run: ``` cd carla make PythonAPI.docs ``` #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** - #### Possible Drawbacks Currently only working in Python 2.7 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1715)

Title: Allow removing on tick callbacks and fixes to client side sensors
Body: I have added an ID to the callbacks so they can be removed ```py id = world.on_tick(lambda x: do_something()) # ... world.remove_on_tick(id) ``` I also finally made client-side sensors deregister their callbacks when they're stopped (there was no way of stopping these sensors before). While doing so I noticed that any exception thrown was ignored actually a lot of exception were thrown all the time due to race conditions between callbacks. Basically their "tick" is called simultaneously from different threads and they were not taking this into account. This was specially bad for the lane invasion sensor since its measurements depend on previous measurements. I have fixed them by making sure either the shared data is const or is properly synchronized using atomics. Now they no longer throw exceptions and its safe to stop them also calling listen a second time replaces the previous callback as server-side sensors do. Fix #1273. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1865)

Title: Allow setting fixed time step at runtime and package in shipping mode
Body: #### Description Found a way for setting the fixed time step mode at runtime I added it to `carla.WorldSettings` as `fixed_delta_seconds`. If `fixed_delta_seconds` is `None` means the simulator is running at variable time step else specifies the delta time in seconds of each time step (1/FPS). Since we can now change this from the client-side we can compile the release version in "Shipping" mode which removes a lot of debug information and command-line options but runs significantly faster. I have also created a convenient Python script to change maps and configure the simulator to compensate the lack of command-line options. Fixes #1852. #### Drawbacks * We lose a lot of useful debug information when running a release. * It's not possible to specify the map when launching the simulator. * It's not possible to set a fixed time step (`-benchmark -fps=X`) when launching the simulator. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1857)

Title: New python reference
Body: #### Description Since we had some issues parsing the `C++` code to autogenerate the PythonAPI docs we decided to have a few `YAML` files with the Python documentation. Regarding #1333 this same method will be used to easily generate Python [stub files](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/#stub-files) in the future. #### How to test Install `MkDocs` if necessary: ``` pip install mkdocs ``` Go to Carla directory and start the `MkDocs` in localhost: ``` cd carla mkdocs serve ``` Open a browser and go to http://127.0.0.1:8000/python_api/ After changing some of the `YAML` files just run: ``` cd carla make PythonAPI.docs ``` #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** - #### Possible Drawbacks Currently only working in Python 2.7 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1814)

Title: Fix Windows build
Body: #### Description See https://github.com/carla-simulator/carla/issues/1894 for more details about the problem. I a few words the problem is that windows compilers change the name of some functions (those who use strings mainly) depending if they need to use UNICODE or ANSI strings. For UNICODE the function name is the same but ending with 'W' and for ANSI they end with 'A'. So for example the function DrawText() of the windows API will change to DrawTextW() or DrawTextA() transparently. That modification is made by the compiler using some kind of #DEFINE preprocessors and that means that the name of the function changes globally in all the code. The problem is that if we need to load that exact function like DrawText() from a non windows DLL (like UE4Editor-Engine.dll from Unreal) the compiler at the end will try to load DrawTextW() or DrawTextA() and that will fail with a linker error similar to: ` error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol "__declspec(dllimport) public: void __cdecl AHUD::DrawTextW(...)" ` So to avoid that we found the way of #UNDEF those function names that gets in conflict with the windows translation doing for example #UNDEF DrawText() We also add a little fix for the strings shown on screen because depending of the camera orientation they were shown at position 0 0. Fixes # 1894 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Windows * **Python version(s):** Any * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22.1 #### Possible Drawbacks Those functions that we UNDEF will not work if we try to use them as windows API unless you directly use the 'W' or 'A' versions instead. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1910)

Title: Fixes for synchronous mode
Body: **TLDR:** I made `tick` and `apply_settings` synchronize automatically with the server so users don't need to manually wait for tick. Unfortunately with this old recipes using `wait_for_tick` will fail. - - - #### Description ~~Requires #1802.~~ Currently we recommend using synchronous mode by calling "tick" and "wait_for_tick" on each iteration ```py while True: world.tick() # Initialize a new "tick" in the simulator. world.wait_for_tick() # Wait until we listen to the new tick. # ... ``` but there is a race condition in here; although unlikely it can happen that the tick arrives before we start waiting for it and we end up having a dead-lock. It's a difficult problem to solve cause we meed to synchronize two servers sending data asynchronously (rpc and streaming). The "tick" method sends a cue to the simulator via RPC but "wait_for_tick" listens to the tick event received each update via streaming. See also #1795. However we can synchronize the `tick` method by returning the id of the newly started frame (this way we make sure the tick was applied upon function return and also we guarantee the id of the frame we're expecting). For convenience `apply_setting` can return too the id of the frame when the settings took effect with this we know for sure at which frame the synchronous mode started. EDIT: I also made `tick` and `apply_settings` block until the new tick is received so no need to manually loop waiting for the state to be updated. I have written a Python example using these two changes to synchronize the output of several sensors. I think we can add something similar to the API maybe in C++ to make the synchronous mode easier to use EDIT: Now this example is in synchronous_mode.py. ```py try: import queue except ImportError: import Queue as queue class CarlaSyncMode(object): def __init__(self world *sensors): self.world = world self.sensors = sensors self.frame = None self._queues = [] def __enter__(self): settings = self.world.get_settings() settings.synchronous_mode = True self.frame = self.world.apply_settings(settings) def make_queue(register_event): q = queue.Queue() register_event(q.put) self._queues.append(q) make_queue(self.world.on_tick) for sensor in self.sensors: make_queue(sensor.listen) return self def tick(self timeout): self.frame = self.world.tick() data = [self._retrieve_data(q timeout) for q in self._queues] assert all(x.frame == self.frame for x in data) return data def __exit__(self type value traceback): settings = self.world.get_settings() settings.synchronous_mode = False self.world.apply_settings(settings) def _retrieve_data(self queue timeout): while True: data = queue.get(timeout=timeout) if data.frame == self.frame: return data ``` An example script with this context manager ```py client = carla.Client('localhost' 2000) client.set_timeout(2.0) world = client.get_world() sensors = [] try: sensors.append(world.spawn_actor( world.get_blueprint_library().find('sensor.camera.rgb') carla.Transform())) sensors.append(world.spawn_actor( world.get_blueprint_library().find('sensor.camera.depth') carla.Transform())) sensors.append(world.spawn_actor( world.get_blueprint_library().find('sensor.camera.semantic_segmentation') carla.Transform())) with CarlaSyncMode(world *sensors) as sync_mode: while True: data = sync_mode.tick(timeout=1.0) snapshot = data[0] for n item in enumerate(data[1:]): item.save_to_disk('_out/%01d_%08d' % (n sync_mode.frame)) finally: for sensor in sensors: sensor.destroy() ``` --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1803)

Title: Improve sync mode performance
Body: #### Description High FPS synchronous_mode * TCP no_delay option enabled to allow high fps otherwise sometimes get stuck in 20 FPS due to 40ms network delay for small packaets * Avoids Deadlock: https://github.com/carla-simulator/carla/issues/2038 * Max FPS benchmarking client utilities in Cpp and Pyhton * Small productivity improvements: run server without capturing mouse in Viewport Fixes # Avoids Deadlock in high speed synchronous_mode #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.6 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22.2 #### Possible Drawbacks Current mechanism of avoiding deadlocks is hacking but did not affect maximum FPS possible for the server and client. Still it might spam the network more and use more CPU. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2070)

Title: Implementation of the new traffic manager
Body: ### Make sure to check the README file before testing since modifications might have to be done on some files before running it. #### Description A new implementation for the traffic manager has been developed. There are several modules all of them containing a description of the functionalities they provide. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7.12 and 3.5.2 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Since it is not using the trigger boxes of the autopilot some changes have to be made on different maps in order for it to avoid running the following traffic lights on a red semaphore: - Town03 BP_TrafficLight01 the bounding box for the semaphore has to be moved out of the junction. - Town04 AmericanLights_Town04_03 the bounding box for the semaphore has to be moved out of the junction. For a similar reason in Town03 the junction on SM_RoadTown03_116 is correctly managed only for the autopilot and should be modified to give it a better regulation. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1951)

Title: Osi grpc comm
Body: **Feature Request** _Adding new module osi_grpc_communication_module._ **Description** - The module provides a standardized interface to connect CARLA with third party tools. - Module uses the gRPC (google remote procedure call) to send the groundtruth measurement data of the host_vehicle and the non_player_agents (vehicles) with OSI standardization (Open Simulation Interface) at every frame in the episode. - All the proto_to_python generated files are present with the module. they can be readily used for the compilation and working. - the origional .proto files are also present for the manipulaiton and advancement. - osi_grpc.proto is used to generate the .py version of the request with protoc and a special gRPC plugin **Where has this been tested?** **Platform(s):** Windows 10 x64 **Python version(s):** Python 3.6 **Unreal Engine version(s):** UE 4.18.3 **- CARLA version(s):** 0.8.4 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/997)

Title: Fixed bugs of importing assets
Body: #### Description Refactored code and fixed issues regarding scale materials and semantic segmentation when importing maps to Unreal Engine. Fixes #1911 and #1886 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04LTS * **Python version(s):** 2.7.12 and 3.5.2 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Import process might take more time since the `import.py` script will invoke the `MoveAssetsCommandlet` for moving the meshes and then `PrepareAssetsForCookingCommandlet` for preparing the map. This is done since moving meshes and preparing maps are done asynchronously inside Unreal Engine therefore we can not invoke both processes in the same execution of the commandlet. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2068)

Title: Extended RGB sensor
Body: #### Description I've added more control over the RGB camera sensor so you can work with them as a real camera. All the currently available RGB camera settings can be modified like this: ```py # Sensor camera_bp.set_attribute('sensor_tick' str(0.0)) # Image camera_bp.set_attribute('image_size_x' str(800)) camera_bp.set_attribute('image_size_y' str(600)) camera_bp.set_attribute('gamma' str(2.2)) # Camera (used for manual exposure and depth of field) camera_bp.set_attribute('fov' str(90.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('shutter_speed' str(60.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('iso' str(1200.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('fstop' str(1.4)) # Aperture is 1.0 / fstop camera_bp.set_attribute('min_fstop' str(1.2)) # Maximum Aperture camera_bp.set_attribute('blade_count' str(5)) # Exposure ("manual" by default) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_mode' str('manual')) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_compensation' str(3.0)) # Exposure - histogram specific (used when "exposure_mode" == "histogram") camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_min_bright' str(0.1)) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_max_bright' str(2.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_speed_up' str(3.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('exposure_speed_down' str(1.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('calibration_constant' str(16.0)) # Depth of field camera_bp.set_attribute('focal_distance' str(1000.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('blur_amount' str(1.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('blur_radius' str(0.0)) # Motion Blur camera_bp.set_attribute('motion_blur_intensity' str(0.45)) camera_bp.set_attribute('motion_blur_max_distortion' str(0.35)) camera_bp.set_attribute('motion_blur_min_object_screen_size' str(0.1)) # Tonemapper camera_bp.set_attribute('slope' str(0.88)) camera_bp.set_attribute('toe' str(0.55)) camera_bp.set_attribute('shoulder' str(0.26)) camera_bp.set_attribute('black_clip' str(0.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('white_clip' str(0.04)) # Color camera_bp.set_attribute('temp' str(6500.0)) camera_bp.set_attribute('tint' str(0.0)) # Other camera_bp.set_attribute('enable_postprocess_effects' str(True)) ``` _in this example they all are set to the default value_ More information about these attributes can be found in the UE4 official docs: [Automatic Exposure](https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-US/Engine/Rendering/PostProcessEffects/AutomaticExposure/index.html) [Cinematic DOF Methods](https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-US/Engine/Rendering/PostProcessEffects/DepthOfField/CinematicDOFMethods/index.html) [Color Grading](https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-US/Engine/Rendering/PostProcessEffects/ColorGrading/index.html) #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 & 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22.2 #### Possible Drawbacks I've exposed everything as it is in UE4. The final RGB output can be different than expected because different settings going on in the weather system is done un UE4 blueprints. This will be investigated in the future. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1950)

Title: SafeDistanceSensor detect vehicles and pedestrians around hero vehicle
Body: #### Description Add a Box Overlapping based SafeDistanceSenser for detecting vehicles and pedestrians around hero vehicle #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7.12 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks 1. Only return `actor.type_id`. Need RPC calls further to retrieve necessary message eg. bounding box. Return `actor` from streaming server directly serialized by reusing `MSGPACK` designed for RPC is another option. But it contains lots of redundant info in the aspect of specific application eg. providing the ground truth perception result for AD stack. Further work should be custom the return value and serialization data structure and method for specific application. 2. Only use box overlapping to detect vehicles and pedestrians around hero vehicle lack of the consideration of shading of view. Add further filters such as raytracing and map-based geometry filtering is a better choice. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2115)

The imlementation is using the AD RSS library (https://github.com/intel/ad-rss-lib). Currently only some road structures are supported. All vehicles must be on the same road segment. Intersection handling is missing. Integration into LibCarla and PythonAPI are optional and available through additional extended make targets. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** Python 2.7 and Python 3.5 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Additional build variant required as AD RSS library is (currently) only supported on Linux. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1935)

Title: Radar implementation
Body: #### Description A radar sensor has been added to Carla. It uses raycasting to detect objects in the level and retrieves its position and velocity. Right now the point distribution is uniform this can be changed in the server's code. As you will see in the API docs you have available two new classes: `RadarMeasurement` and `RadarDetection` to access the new Radar information. #### Code example ```py ... # Get radar blueprint radar_bp = bp_lb.filter('sensor.other.radar')[0] # Set Radar attributes by default are: radar_bp.set_attribute('horizontal_fov' '30') # degrees radar_bp.set_attribute('vertical_fov' '30') # degrees radar_bp.set_attribute('points_per_second' '1500') radar_bp.set_attribute('range' '100') # meters # Spawn the radar radar = world.spawn_actor(radar_bp carla.Transform()) # Create a radar's callback that just prints the data def radar_callback(weak_radar sensor_data): self = weak_radar() if not self: return for detection in sensor_data: print('depth: ' + str(detection.depth)) # meters print('azimuth: ' + str(detection.azimuth)) # rad print('altitude: ' + str(detection.altitude)) # rad print('velocity: ' + str(detection.velocity)) # m/s weak_radar = weakref.ref(radar) # Bind the callback radar.listen(lambda sensor_data: radar_callback(weak_radar sensor_data)) ``` #### Visualization example The example shows a vehicle approaching from the right side of an static radar. Notice the red dots on the right side. ![radar_plot25](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6574060/70447197-a72b2900-1a9e-11ea-9597-2f450ac0c9c5.gif) #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks If more than 300k rays are sent in total in the level the framerate might drop. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2280)

Title: Bernatx pedestrian crossing
Body: #### Description Pedestrians now have new features: - They will try to avoid vehicles - Only a % specified by the user can walk through the road the others that can not must use the cross zones - At regular intervals pedestrians will get a new route to follow if they are blocked by some reason - Pedestrians can use three types of geometry (sidewalk road and cross zones). Fixes # 1899 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Linux and Windows * **Python version(s):** 2.8 and 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Right now the definition of cross zones is done by hand. We are in the process of creating a tutorial about this subject. The process involves export geometry at different .OBJ files (using our Carla Exporter from Unreal Editor) then use a Python script to merge all that geometry in one file .OBJ and then import that .OBJ file in Recast (our fork version) and build the binary file .BIN. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2191)

Title: Added IMU and Radar visualization to manual_control py
Body: #### Description Added support for realtime IMU and Radar data visualization in `manual_control.py`. - IMU is always enabled at the left panel + This means that now the compass is rotated but it now correctly represents the OpenDrive's North. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15848712/70604842-a5c24380-1bf9-11ea-8ae6-c258ae11a6e0.png) - Radar's visualization is disabled by default and it can be enabled pressing the `g` key. This has not been assigned to any keyboard number as you would expect this is because I found the visualization easier to understand and validate using other cameras: ![radar_pr](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15848712/70606700-5847d580-1bfd-11ea-94b4-22bf3bc75236.gif) The red intensity means negative speed and the blue one means positive speed in sensor coordinates. Depth azimuth and elevation are used to calculate the 3d position of each detection. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2292)

Title: Parsing OpenDRIVE crosswalks
Body: #### Description New PythonAPI function to parse the OpenDRIVE file and return a list with all the points that define each crosswalk. That functionality is needed because we can define crosswalk zones with RoadRunner and they are exported only with the OpenDRIVE file of the map. Then we can parse that information and generate the geometry needed for the pedestrian's navigation system to know where they can cross the roads. This API is used automatically in the Docker import pipeline. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18 Windows 10 * **Python version(s):** Python 2 and 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Currently there is some angle distortion and the crosswalks need to be extended about 1 meter in each extreme so they cover any space until the sidewalk (Road_Gutter Road_Curb...). --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2289)

Title: Fix Low Epic quality levels transition
Body: #### Description This PR will fix the transition from Epic / Low quality settings. Two problems were found in version Carla 0.9.7: First Unreal was writing the last quality settings to a file in /Saved/ folder and was reading and applying those settings without taking care of the desired quality settings that the user could specify. We have fixed this thanks to the help of BenAscent who pointed the way to disable the writing of those settings. Second when enabling low-quality settings the autoexposure was disabled but a value of Exposure Compensation of 4.5 was applied what made the image brighter than usual. We fixed that forcing autoexposure to be enabled also at low-quality level. Fixes #2336 #2335 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu and Windows * **Python version(s):** 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks If you had the problem of bright image in low-quality settings probably you will need to remove the /Saved/ folder because there Unreal has written the last quality settings. Just clean that folder and run again with any Epic or Low quality settings. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2352)

Title: Added to BoundingBox methods Contains GetWorldVertices and GetLocalVertices
Body: #### Description Added new methods to BoundingBox: - BoundingBox::Contains: whether a point in world space is contained by the bbox. - BoundingBox::GetWorldVertices: returns a list of the 8 vertices of the bbox in world space. - BoundingBox::GetLocalVertices: returns a list of the 8 vertices of the bbox in local space. Exposed them to the Python API as: - contains - get_world_vertices - get_local_vertices. To implement this I have also modified Transform and Rotation to be able to transform points back and forth: - Transform::InverseTransformPoint - Rotation::RotatePoint (moved from Transform::TransformPoint to its own function) - Transform::InverseRotatePoint Also added a tests that make sure that transformation back and forth are coherent to one another (P after being transformed and untransformed should yield P again). And another test for local and world vertices making sure that they match when using the bbox Transform. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7.17 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2392)

Title: Allow waypoint creation from OpenDRIVE
Body: #### Description We added a new function for the Python API where you can request a new waypoint giving a set of parameters from the openDRIVE file. The parameters are the road id the lane id and the distance from the road start. An example is: ```py m = world.get_map() w = m.get_waypoint_xodr(10 2 1) ``` It requests a waypoint placed a 1m of the lane id 2 from the road id 10. For this waypoint we can request a lane id of 0 which means that the waypoint will be placed at the centerline of the road. If any of the parameters are wrong then the result is None instead of a waypoint. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Windows * **Python version(s):** 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2426)

Title: Bugfixes about recorder
Body: #### Description There are some bug fixes in the recorder system: 1) Fixing the camera following when a new map is loaded by the recorder. The wrong variable was used in that case ('FollowingId' instead of the 'ThisFollowingId') 2) Fixing positions at start of replayer if another replayer was play. The second time the replayer is called the actors were interpolated with its previous position and the new one but at the beginning the previous position was where the previous replayer leaves the actor so the actors were interpolated from its current position and the new position they need to go and the effect was that the actors were sliding fast to its new position for a short time (only in 1 frame). 3) The API function 'show_recorder_file_info' was showing the wrong parent id of an actor. It was showing the same id than the child actor because was using the wrong field name ('DatabaseId' instead of 'DatabaseIdParent'). Fixes # #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu * **Python version(s):** 2.7 and 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.21 #### Possible Drawbacks None --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1537)

Title: Glopez intersection anticipation
Body: #### Description A new algorithm has been added for vehicles about to enter an intersection that detects if there is a stopped vehicle right after the intersection. If so the vehicle will stop before entering such intersection instead of doing so in the middle of it reducing the possibilities of obstructing the traffic. The algorithm basically loops through the buffer (or keeps adding waypoints to it) until some key waypoints are found: - Initial waypoint: Start of the junction - Safe waypoint: End of the junction - Final waypoint: Location of the vehicle after the junction #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Linux 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7.17 and 3.6.9 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks The algorithm relies heavily on the OpenDrive to know whether or not a waypoint is part of a junction which might create weird behaviours in some intersections. Tests should focus on the roundabout and very closeby intersections. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2355)

Title: Joel mb traffic manager
Body: #### Description This PR adds destruction of stuck vehicles. It checks for vehicles without moving (i.e. velocity minor than a threshold) and increments an internal counter for each vehicle. If this counter is greater than a threshold the vehicle is considered to be stuck a it is destroyed. A threshold to avoid consecutive destructions has been added (elapsed time between destructions). #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7.17 and 3.6.9 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Removing vehicles that are not really stuck or removing vehicles that are not responsible of the blockage. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2385)

Title: Axel1092 extend map api
Body: #### Description Added new functions to `client::Waypoint`: - `GetPrevious`: similar to `GetNext` but moves in the opposite direction. - `GetNextUntilLaneEnd`: returns waypoints until the end of the lane separated by the specified distance. - `GetPreviousUntilLaneStart`: returns waypoints until the start of the lane separated by the specified distance. - `GetJunction`: returns the `carla::Junction` object of the junction corresponding to the waypoint positon. Added `client::Junction` class with the following functions: - `GetId`: return the OpenDRIVE junction id. - `GetBoundingBox`: returns the bounding box of the junction which is computed in `MapBuilder` class. - `GetWaypoints`: returns a pair of Waypoints for each lane in the junction indicating the start and end of the lane. Updated the Python API and documentation with the corresponding functions and class. Edited `lane_explorer.py` to draw junctions (waypoints and bounding box). Testing: use the lane_explorer.py to see the effect of these functions. Change `next()` to `previous/get_next_until_lane_end/get_previous_until_lane_start()` to see the effects of the corresponding functions. Added function in `client::Map`: - `GetJunctionWaypoints`: returns waypoints of a junction. Added function in `road::Map`: - `GetJunctionWaypoints`: returns waypoints of a junction. Added function in `road::MapBuilder`: - `CreateJunctionBoundingBoxes`: computes the bounding boxes of all junctions #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** UBUNTU 18.04 * **Python version(s):** Python2.7.17 and Python3.6.9 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Computing the bounding boxes of the junction happens in the `MapBuilder` class which also runs in the simulator. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2380)

Title: Extended OpenDRIVE geometry support
Body: #### Description Added spiral geometry support in `Geometry.cpp`. Added library files `odrSpiral.cpp` and `odrSpiral.h` to support spirals. Added 2 Rtree templated classes (using points and segments) using boost rtrees to accelerate nearest neighbour search. Added function Set in `CubicPolynomial` class. Added geometry: poly3 and paramPoly3 (the OpenDRIVE viewer crashes with some configurations for paramPoly3). Added map_viewer.py to visualize a xodr file without unreal. Usage: python map_viewer.py -f=path/to/file.xodr Fixes #1904 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** Python2 and Python3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Constructing the Rtrees involves some preprocess lasting up to 10 seconds for big maps (like Town10). Edit: I optimized this but for larger maps it could take some time. paramPoly3 gives the same results as the odrViewer for pRange=arcLength. For pRange=normalized the odrViewer produces the same result as using arcLength which looks like a bug. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2425)

Title: Add german international keyboard support to manual_control py
Body: manual_control.py uses the backquote key ("`") to change the used sensor. That is an issue on German keyboard layouts (and potentially a number of other international layouts) since there is no backquote key in this layout (it's not a single keypress you need to press a key and another key to create a backquote character). I propose to use the "n" key instead which is not used so far and which I assume is produced by a single key press on a lot if not all layouts. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1984)

Title: Server side sensor filters
Body: #### Description Added support for CUDA and CPU server-side based sensor filters (for custom sensor modeling: e.g. to create custom lens or color profile output). ![example lens distortion + color perception](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5066960/66928808-42b99380-f032-11e9-893f-76d9901cd507.gif) #### Possible Drawbacks - Works only on OpenGL ignored on Vulcan. - Slight impact on performance when activated (when 'filter_name' attribute is added to blueprint): > 4K camera sensor without filter: avg. 10 FPS > 4K camera sensor with CUDA inverseFilter: avg. 7 FPS #### Checklist - [x] Your branch is up-to-date with the `master` branch and tested with latest changes - [x] Extended the README / documentation if necessary - [x] Code compiles correctly - [x] All tests passing with `make check` - [x] If relevant update CHANGELOG.md with your changes --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2171)

Title: New agent behaviors
Body: #### Description Behavior Agent implements an agent that navigates scenes to reach a given target destination by computing the shortest possible path to it using PID control to modulate its velocity and steering. This agent can correctly follow traffic signs speed limitations traffic lights while also taking into account nearby vehicles. Lane changing decisions can be taken by analyzing the surrounding environment such as overtaking or tailgating avoidance. Adding to these are possible behaviors the agent can also keep safety distance from a car in front of it by tracking the instantaneous time to collision and keeping it above a certain range. Finally different sets of behaviors are encoded in the agent from cautious to a more aggressive ones. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** Python 2.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks The new automatic_control.py doesn't include anymore the possibility of using the older agents. edit: this is now fixed it still allows using older agents. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2091)

Title: Forward header offset directly to the Array constructor
Body: #### Description In LibCarla/source/carla/sensor/data/RawEpisodeState.h we have: ``` explicit RawEpisodeState(RawData data) : Super(std::move(data)) { Super::SetOffset(Serializer::header_offset); } ``` The call of the constructor of the base class will trigger the following code in LibCarla/source/carla/sensor/data/Array.h: ``` explicit Array(size_t offset RawData data) : SensorData(data) _data(std::move(data)) { SetOffset(offset); } explicit Array(RawData data) : Array(0u std::move(data)) {} void SetOffset(size_t offset) { _offset = offset; DEBUG_ASSERT(_data.size() >= _offset); DEBUG_ASSERT((_data.size() - _offset) % sizeof(T) == 0u); DEBUG_ASSERT(begin() <= end()); } ``` So first the second constructor is called which calls the first one with an offset of 0. The first constructor calls SetOffset and this will break because the offset is wrong. Because of that LibCarla/source/carla/sensor/data/RawEpisodeState.h was changed like: ``` explicit RawEpisodeState(RawData data) : Super(Serializer::header_offset std::move(data)) { } ``` Fixes #2193 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Windows 10 64 bit * **Python version(s):** 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2194)

Title: Adding Ignore Hero to Replayer Issue 1769
Body: #### Description A new parameter has been added at the time of replaying a session where you can choose if the recorded hero vehicles will be replayed or not. If they are not then they can drive freely while the recorder system is replaying all other vehicles. That allows to the hero vehicles to test different strategies while the simulation is the same every time. The parameter is the `-i` or `--ignore_hero` For example: `./start_replaying.py -f recorded.log -i` Fixes # 1605 Fixes # 1769 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 and 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Take care with the collisions because the replayed vehicles will not react to collisions from the hero and they will maintain always the recorded position. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/1807)

Title: Standalone OpenDRIVE support
Body: #### Description Basically added the functionality to create a new map in the server from raw OpenDRIVE data even remotely from the client. ![town01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15848712/74855660-468f5680-5341-11ea-8222-1e406086e87b.png) _Example using the OpenDRIVE file from Town01_ - **C++** - Added `carla::geom::Mesh` a minimal mesh data container validator and exporter. - Added export support for [Wavefront `.obj` file](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_.obj_file). This also allows the Recast library to consume these files and generate the binaries for our pedestrians to walk on the generated sidewalks. - Added `carla::road::Map::GenerateGeometry(double distance)` that builds a mesh based on OpenDRIVE data. The sidewalks are generated with some height above the roads. - Created the Unreal's AActor `OpenDriveGenerator` that uses the generated mesh to build an Unreals procedural mesh with collisions on it so the cars can drive over them. - **PythonAPI** - Added `calra.client.generate_opendrive_world(opendrive)` that loads a map with custom OpenDRIVE basic physical topology. This works similarly to client.load_map(map_name) but it expects the OpenDRIVE data as `string`. - **Content** - Added a new map `Content/Maps/OpenDriveMap.umap` that hosts those maps generated from raw OpenDRIVE. #### How to test Updated the `PythonAPI/util/config.py` with the argument `--xodr-path` (or `-x`) that expects a path to an OpenDRIVE (.xodr) file and loads this new custom map. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 & 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks The roads can contain some gaps (especially on junctions) since OpenDRIVE does not define the ground itself but the drivable zones of it. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2491)

Title: Fix import pipeline crashes and missing semantic tagging
Body: #### Description * Changed the import python script to avoid running commands that would crash if no pedestrian navmesh is available. * Changed the Move assets commandlet to properly recognize the static meshes and put them in the right folder * Changed the Prepare assets for cooking commandlet to not overwrite the correct map with one without the semantic lane data #### Fixes The import pipeline: * Made assumptions on the optional data structures * Didn't properly place the static meshes for semantic tagging * Generated semantic information saved the map deleted the info from the map and then saved the map again Fixes issues https://github.com/carla-simulator/carla/issues/2332 and https://github.com/carla-simulator/carla/issues/2340 #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Windows 10 64 bits Ubuntu Linux 18.04 64 bits * **Python version(s):** Python 3.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks * A potential side effect is that the import process now doesn't treat pedestrian nav meshes as necessary meaning that if someone is expecting it to crash when they are not available the script won't stop. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2390)

Title: Taking account of the very last waypoint buffer
Body: This PR is a small hotfix that lets the vehicle go exactly to the desired location instead of stopping before reaching the destination. Previously the local planner stops sending control commands when __waypoints_queue_ is empty. However there is also a __waypoint_buffer_ which is not empty. The very last round when the vehicle reaches the desired destination not only the __waypoints_queue_ is empty but also the __waypoint_buffer_ must be empty as well. The way it is now there is always a bias of _self._buffer_size_ number of waypoints to the desired destination. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.6 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks I could not find any usage of function 'def done(self):'. This function might be a deprecated function. Nevertheless I have also updated the function to return the correct value. Previously the second part was always True: if `len(self._waypoints_queue) == 0` then `all([distance_vehicle(wp vehicle_transform) < self._min_distance for wp in self._waypoints_queue])` is always True. So there is no point in having the second part. return len(self._waypoints_queue) == 0 and all([distance_vehicle(wp vehicle_transform) < self._min_distance for wp in self._waypoints_queue] --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2407)

Title: SUMO co simulation beta version
Body: #### Description This PR aims the first version for sumo and carla co-simulations. The following features are synchronized: * Vehicle sync from sumo to carla and carla to sumo (by teleporting the vehicles). * Vehicle lights from sumo to carla and carla to sumo (brake light blinkers emergency light ...) Additionally helper scripts are provided to create sumo vtypes based on carla blueprints. In this way the specifications of the vehicles can be the same in both simulations. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7.17 3.6.9 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks The following features are not yet synchronized: * Pedestrians. * Traffic lights. This may cause collisions with pedestrians and unintended behaviors at junctions with traffic lights. The integration has only been tested thoroughly in town1. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2558)

Title: Doterop traffic lights
Body: #### Description Adds new classes for managing the traffic lights from OpenDRIVE. `TrafficSignComponent`: an unreal component that represents an opendrive signal. Currently only contains the Id. `TrafficLightComponent`: an unreal component that represents a traffic light. Contains the state of the light. `TrafficLightController`: represents an opendrive controller. It holds references to `TrafficLightComponent` and contains the cycle of states (time in green time in yellow etc). `TrafficLightGroup`: represents an opendrive junction and holds references to `TrafficLightController`. It is the one responsible to tick and moves through the cycles. `TrafficLightInterface`: it is an interface to allow the `TrafficLightComponent` to comunicate the light change to the actor that currently owns this component. `TrafficLightManager`: this class is in charge of spawning and registering traffic lights using the information in the opendrive file. It assigns the `TrafficLightComponent` to the corresponding `TrafficLightController` and `TrafficLightGroup`. You need to pull the latest version of the content folder. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks Currently only the unreal engine side is implemented and does not reach the client (future pull request). --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2541)

Title: New behavior agent small changes to manual and automatic control
Body: #### Description I've took my 10 minutes to resurrect this PR hopefully it will be accepted now. Also it includes a few other small changes: * Adds a more realistic throttle to manual_control.py * Adds some checks to automatic_control.py **Both scripts should be tested and approved.** Behavior Agent implements an agent that navigates scenes to reach a given target destination by computing the shortest possible path to it using PID control to modulate its velocity and steering. This agent can correctly follow traffic signs speed limitations traffic lights while also taking into account nearby vehicles. Lane changing decisions can be taken by analyzing the surrounding environment such as overtaking or tailgating avoidance. Adding to these are possible behaviors the agent can also keep safety distance from a car in front of it by tracking the instantaneous time to collision and keeping it above a certain range. Finally different sets of behaviors are encoded in the agent from cautious to a more aggressive ones. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 * **Python version(s):** Python 2.7 & 3.5 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks None. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2508)

Title: Collision avoidance and braking improvements
Body: #### Description * Improved collision negotiation algorithm to be logically more concise and functionally more effective. * Improved lead-vehicle-following behavior by acquiring the lead vehicle's velocity. * Improved crawling approach to achieve precise stopping margin to lead vehicle. * Improved collision candidate filtering to reduce unnecessary computation and prioritize the nearest vehicles in order. * Improved collision stage efficiency by curvature sensitive sparse polygon construction. * Improved collision stage efficiency by faster polygon construction using boost point append instead of W.K.T string-based polygon construction. * Implemented more details in SnippetProfiler for better performance diagnosis. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.6 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2650)

Title: New examples sumo co simulation
Body: #### Description Adding examples of sumo co-simulation for Town01 04 05. Each example contains: * Sumo net (inside `examples/net` folder): `*.net.xml` * Random routes (inside `examples/rou` folder) : `*.rou.xml` * Simulation file: `*.sumocfg` Additionally the following files are shared between the different examples: * `carlavtypes.rou.xml`: Contains the definition of vehicle types based on carla blueprints. * `viewsettings.xml`: view settings configuration for sumo-gui. To run one example: ``` python run_synchronization.py -c examples/Town01.sumocfg ``` On the other hand the file `data/opendrive_netconvert.typ.xml` has been added to allow importing all the opendrive lanes when using `netconvert` (e.g. the sumo nets now contain the sidewalks). Besides this pr fixes small bugs: * Correctly showing a help message when running sumo-gui * Avoiding ticking carla when a vehicle is spawned. * Bigger z offset to spawn vehicles to avoid collisions. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.6.9 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks Adding big files (`*.net.xml`) to the repo. The files are likely to change if the original opendrives are modified. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2673)

Title: Added methods to get trafficlights and trafficsigns from landmarks
Body: #### Description The PythonAPI has been updated to be able to get a TrafficLight or TrafficSign actor from a Landmark. Example: ```python traffic_lights = waypoint.get_landmarks_of_type(100 "1000001") if len(traffic_lights) > 0: traffic_light = self.world.get_traffic_light(traffic_lights[0]) print( traffic_light.state ) print( traffic_light.get_state() ) print( traffic_light.get_green_time() ) print( traffic_light.get_yellow_time() ) print( traffic_light.get_red_time() ) print( traffic_light.get_elapsed_time() ) print( traffic_light.is_frozen() ) print( traffic_light.get_pole_index() ) print( traffic_light.get_group_traffic_lights() ) print( traffic_light.trigger_volume.location ) print( traffic_light.trigger_volume.extent ) ``` #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Linux * **Python version(s):** 2 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2672)

Title: PTV Vissim integration beta version
Body: #### Description This PR aims the first version for PTV-Vissim and carla co-simulations. The following features are synchronized: * Vehicle sync from ptv-vissim to carla and carla to ptv-vissim (by teleporting the vehicles). * Vehicle speed. Additionally an example for Town01 and Town03 is added. To run the example execute: ``` python run_synchronization.py ``` #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Windows 10 * **Python version(s):** 3.7.7 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 #### Possible Drawbacks The following features are not sync: *Pedestrians. *Traffic lights. *Vehicle indicators. This may cause collisions with pedestrians and unintended behaviors at junctions with traffic lights. The integration has only been tested thoroughly in town1. Besides big files (*.inpx) to the repo. The files are likely to change if the original opendrives are modified. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2660)

Title: Hot Fixes For Hybrid Physics Mode
Body: #### Description * Implemented path buffer pruning from both sides to stay consistent with the vehicle velocity. This is to ensure path buffers do not grow to unreasonable sizes incase of incorrect velocity measurement in physics-less mode. * Using a simple linear interpolation for waypoint horizon length with min-max clipping to restrict changes in the size of path buffers to a given velocity range. * Removed vehicle-rear-offset for buffer pruning from the front to ensure path buffer begins from the current point location of the vehicle and forward only. * Implemented vertical position offset in physics-less mode to provide customizable ground clearance. * Restricting longitudinal position offset for teleportation in the forward direction only to mitigate longitudinal oscillations in hybrid physics mode. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.6 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2680)

Title: Fix compilation issue with BullseyeCoverage
Body: Currently CARLA fails to build under Bullseye coverage due to the usage of an overloaded operator&& from Boost.Geometry. This is a limitation of the coverage tool and not Carla's fault however since it can be worked around simply by changing how the operator&& is called it might be a good idea to do this small change in CARLA to avoid someone else stumbling upon this issue again. This PR does not change behaviour simply replaces `a && b` by `operator&&(a b)`. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2691)

Title: Spawn lone traffic lights
Body: #### Description Moved trigger box generation for traffic lights from `ATrafficLightManager` to `UTrafficLightComponent'. Added spawn of traffic lights without controllers when defined outside junctions. The signal needs to fullfill the following conditions for this to happen: - Has no controllers - Is defined outside any junction (standard roads) - It's type corresponds to a traffic light as defined in the OpenDRIVE specification. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** UE4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks A traffic light may be defined outside a junction but may take effect inside one. The traffic light will spawn and behave independently of the other lights in the junction. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2705)

Title: Fixed get_all_landmarks functions returning corrupted landmarks
Body: #### Description This is a quick fix for the functions `get_all_landmarks` `get_all_landmarks_from_id` and `get_all_landmarks_of_type` returning corrupted landmarks. The issue happened when calling these functions in the following way: ``` for landmark in world.get_map().get_all_landmarks(): # do stuff with landmark ``` The call `world.get_map()` calls the simulator to retrieve the OpenDRIVE file and parses the map. Then the call `get_all_landmarks()` retrieves a list of landmarks with contents that points towards the map. After this last call python deletes the map from `world.get_map()` rendering the contents of the landmark list corrupted. This fix adds the necessary shared pointers to the Landmark class to prevent this deletion from happening before the loop is completed. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** UE4.24 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2710)

RssCheck: object conversion done in parallel using tbb Fixes # #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 16.04 / 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2.7 3.5 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.22 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2647)

Title: Standalone Opendrive mode
Body: #### Description Added standalone OpenDRIVE mode. The mesh generation in the OpenDRIVE standalone mode has been greatly improved. Junctions have been polished to avoid inaccuracies especially where uneven lanes joined. Instead of creating the whole map as a unique mesh different fragments are created. Working smaller prevents unexpected issues. Also by dividing the mesh not all of it has to be rendered at a time. This is a step towards a larger goal where the feature will be able to generate huge maps. Added junction smoothing algorithm to prevent roads blocking other roads within junctions. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 2 3 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** UE4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks The junction smoothing is not perfect and may produce bumbs in some situation. Regardless it should allow the vehicles to move through the intersections in the vast majority of situations. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2713)

Title: Sumo traffic lights integration
Body: #### Description This PR adds several improvements regarding sumo co-simulation. 1. Synchronization of traffic lights. This synchronization can be split into two different functionalities: * The `netconvert_carla.py` script (inside the `util` folder) that generates sumo nets based on opendrive files. Internally it uses netconvert to generate the net and inserts manually the traffic light landmarks retrieved from the opendrive. This is done to reduce differences with the traffic lights spwaned in carla. Example of usage: ```sh python netconvert_carla.py --output Test.net.xml ``` * The actual synchronization of traffic lights. The user is able to select which simulator has the control over the traffic lights. Example of usage: ```sh python run_synchronization.py -c examples/TestTLS.sumocfg --tls-manager carla. ``` The `tls-manager` argument may take the following values: `sumo` `carla` `none` The synchronization of traffic lights only works with opendrive files with signals. Therefore this feature is not available for the current towns of carla. 2. The script `spawn_npc_sumo.py` that imitates the functionality of the traditional `spawn_npc.py` but using sumo instead of traffic manager. This script is only available for Town01 04 05. #### Where has this been tested? * **Platform(s):** Ubuntu 18.04 * **Python version(s):** 3.6.9 2.7.17 * **Unreal Engine version(s):** 4.24 #### Possible Drawbacks --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/carla-simulator/carla/2714)
